Award.AwardTitle: Relativistic Heavy Ion Collision Studies at the LHC and RHIC
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is primarily to carry out experiments with relativistic heavy ion collisions. The principal investigators are T. J. Humanic and M. A. Lisa, of the Department of Physics at The Ohio State University. Our goals for the high-energy program are threefold. Firstly, we will study the space-time properties of the extremely dense matter created at in collisions between heavy nuclei at the highest achievable energies. It is believed that this matter is a quark-gluon plasma (QGP), characterized by colored degrees of freedom at the microscopic scale. The second activity is to study the bulk phase structure of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), believed to be the correct theory of the Strong interaction between partons. This will be achieved by varying the conditions of the collision to lower energies, to probe the transition(s) between confined and deconfined matter. In particular, we plan to perform a novel analysis as a function of the collision energy, measuring coordinate-space anisotropies and dynamics. Thirdly, we will take the tools developed to study bulk physics in heavy ion collisions, and apply them to hadronic(p+p) collisions at similar energies. We will look particularly for collective behaviour(flow) in hadronic collisions. If our initial reports of such flow in ultrarelativistic p+p collisions are confirmed at higher energies, this raises important issues about the nature of flow, and the nature of the initial self-interacting state, itself. In the present grant ultrarelativistic heavy ion collisions will be studied with Au-Au collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), and with Pb-Pb collisions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva. RHIC started delivering Au-Au collisions in Summer 2000, and the LHC, which is the highest energy heavy ion accelerator now in operation, began delivering Pb-Pb collisions at the end of 2010. In order to look for signatures that a phase transition to Quark Matter has taken place, one must study the properties of the particles produced in the collisions, such as particle momenta and multiplicities of each type that can be detected (e.g. pions, kaons, protons, and more exotic particles). This will be done at both RHIC and the LHC using the large acceptance detectors available in the STAR and ALICE experiments, respectively, which can sample most of the interesting particles per collision. The information obtained in this way can be used to determine, for example, the physical size of the interaction region (using two-particle interferometry), the temperatures reached in the collisions (from particle momentum distributions) and exotic particle production such as strange baryons.

Besides the intellectual merit described above, there are broader impacts to society of this proposal in the areas of education, technology and computing. Since undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers will play key roles in this project, training will be provided to these groups in how to carry out research in large collaborations and in general problem solving skills. Since this research requires large-scale computing in order to acquire and analyze data on the teraflop and terabyte scale, new methods in information science, such as computing grid systems, will be developed, which can enhance the computing power of society as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our main goal of this grant was to study hot and dense matter produced in proton-­proton and heavy­-ion collisions at the Large Hadron Collider at the CERN laboratory (ALICE experment) and at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory (STAR experiment). Another important goal was to train graduate students in the methods of physics research.

Matter created in these collisions is thought to be composed of a plasma of free quarks and gluons released from their confinement within the colliding protons and heavy ions called the Quark-Gluon Plasma. This allows us to study the properties of such a system and to test the theory of quarks and gluons, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), which has been very successful in describing the behavior of these particles in other types of experiments. Our experiments have focused on understanding three aspects of the physics in these collisions: 1) global polarization of the Lambda particle in RHIC collisions, 2) measurement of the size of the interaction region and its dependence on the kinematics of the emitted particles in both RHC and LHC collisions, and 3) the quark composition of the a0 particle from LHC collisions.

Analyzing STAR data from the RHIC Beam Energy Scan, one of our graduate students (I. Upsal) has discovered global Lambda polarization in gold-gold collisions. This is the first observation, in any experiment, of this effect, which is predicted to probe the QCD spin­-orbit coupling and vorticity of the Quark Gluon Plasma. Vorticity is a fundamental feature of any fluid, and this discovery opens the door to an entirely new area of inquiry in our understanding of colored matter under extreme conditions. A Nature paper on this work has been recentlly published and Nature chose to highlight this paper on its front cover (see figure).

Our group has been active in using the tool of two-particle femtoscopy to measure the size and particle-emission strength of the hot matter produced in both RHIC and LHC collisions. Five of our graduate students have been involved in this work, studing pion-pion femtoscopy at RHIC (J. Campbell), and kaon-kaon (M. Steinpreis), Lambda-Lambda (J. Salzwedel), kaon-Lambda (J. Buxton) and pion-pion (A. Kubera) femtoscopy at the LHC. A figure plotting extracted radii of the collision interaction region vs. the average momentum of the emitted particles published in Physical Review C is shown. The collision system is 2.76 TeV Pb-Pb collisions from the LHC ALICE collaboration. The decrease in the radii as particle momentum increases is a signature of hydrodynamic flow in these collisions. The neutral-kaon-pair points in the figure were measured by one of our graduate students (M. Steinpreis) for his thesis work. Several of these other femtoscopy studies have been written up as paper drafts and will soon be submitted to journals for publication. A novel application of femtoscopy from our group has been studying the correlations between neutral and charged kaons, i.e. K0s-Kch femtoscopy. This combination of particles has never been studied before with femtoscopy. This is interesting because the interaction between the particles is due to the presence of the a0 particle, which is though to be a possile 4-quark state which has never been seen for such light particles. The ALICE collaboration has submitted a paper on this study to Physics Letters B, in which we state that we see results consistent with a 4-quark a0 particle. Two figures from this paper showing comparisons between the radius and strength parameters extracted from K0s-Kch and identical kaon experiments are shown. The fact that the K0s-Kch results agree with the other experiments suggest the 4-quark nature of the a0 particle.

Besides the intellectual merit described above, there have been broader impacts to society from this grant in the areas of education, technology and computing. Since graduate students have played key roles in this project, training was provided to them in how to carry out research in large collaborations and in general problem solving skills. Since this research requires large-scale computing in order to acquire and analyze data on the teraflop and terabyte scale, new methods in information science, such as computing grid systems, have been tested by our analyses which can enhance the computing power of society as a whole.
